pathway: Pharmacy First - Acute Sore Throat (≥5 years)
notes: Scope: non-pregnant individuals ≥5 years with suspected streptococcal sore throat. Exclude pregnant people <16 years, immunocompromised patients with red flags, and those needing immediate medical attention.
Use FeverPAIN to guide practice: Fever (>38 °C); purulence; rapid attendance (≤3 days); severely inflamed tonsils; no cough/coryza. Score each criterion 1 point.
Provide TARGET Respiratory Tract Infection leaflets for self-care advice and reinforce analgesia (paracetamol/ibuprofen), fluid intake, rest, and avoidance of smoke exposure.
Explain that antibiotics shorten symptoms by only ~1 day even in high scores; shared decision-making should reflect severity, patient preference, and clinical judgement.
Refer urgently if scarlet fever, peritonsillar abscess (quinsy), epiglottitis, sepsis, or suspected head/neck cancer features develop.

decisionTree.title: Consider the risk of deterioration or serious illness
decisionTree.question: Does the patient have complications or high-risk features?

airwayOrSepsis: Drooling, voice change, stridor, severe respiratory distress.
Sepsis criteria or NEWS2 trigger (tachycardia, hypotension, rigors).
immediateReferral: Severe dehydration or inability to swallow fluids.

yes.title: Onward referral
actions: Escalate to GP, urgent care, or emergency services as appropriate.
Consider NEWS2 calculation prior to calling 999/A&E.
Do not supply antibiotics via PGD when complications suspected.

no.title: Red flag assessment
no.question: Does the patient have any of these features?

redFlags: Signs of scarlet fever (strawberry tongue, sandpaper rash, circumoral pallor).
Signs of suspected head/neck cancer (persistent hoarseness, dysphagia, unilateral sore throat >3 weeks).
Immunosuppression (e.g. chemotherapy, HIV with low CD4, high-dose steroids).

yes.title: Refer for medical assessment
actions: Arrange GP review or appropriate specialist pathway.
Document red flag findings and advise patient to seek urgent care if symptoms worsen.
Provide symptomatic relief guidance while awaiting review.

scoring: Give 1 point each: fever >38 °C, purulence, rapid presentation (≤3 days), severely inflamed tonsils, no cough/coryza.
Scores 2–3: intermediate probability—safety-net and consider delayed strategy.
Scores 4–5: high probability—shared decision about immediate antibiotic.

next.title: Self-care and pain relief
actions: Explain that antibiotics are not indicated; offer OTC analgesia (paracetamol/ibuprofen).
Advise warm fluids, honey (over 1 year), and rest; avoid smoking exposure.
Encourage return if symptoms significantly worsen or persist beyond 1 week.
next.followUp: Arrange pharmacist review if symptoms fail to improve after 1 week.

next.title: Self-care + watchful waiting
actions: Discuss that antibiotics offer limited benefit; focus on analgesia and hydration.
Provide TARGET RTI leaflet and agree to reassess if no improvement after 3–5 days.
Document shared plan; consider delayed antibiotic only after reassessment if symptoms persist or worsen.
next.followUp: Ask patient to return in 3–5 days if symptoms unchanged for pharmacist reassessment.

next.title: Gateway point
next.question: Based on shared decision-making, are symptoms severe enough to justify immediate antibiotics?

mild: Mild-to-moderate pain with ability to swallow and no systemic illness—consider analgesia first.
severe: Severe throat pain, high fever, pronounced tonsillar exudate, or patient preference after counselling.

yes.title: Reported penicillin allergy
yes.question: Is there a confirmed penicillin allergy?

yes.title: Erythromycin (pregnant with penicillin allergy)
formulations: Oral suspension 125 mg/5 mL, 250 mg/5 mL
yes.route: Oral, ideally with food to improve tolerance.
plus: Discuss potential GI side effects and adherence for full 5-day course.
Advise to seek care if jaundice, severe vomiting, or rash occurs.
yes.followUp: Review if symptoms persist or worsen after 3 days.

no.title: Clarithromycin (penicillin allergy)
no.route: Oral with water; take with or without food.
plus: Encourage hydration and continue self-care strategies.
no.followUp: Seek review if no improvement after 3 days or sooner if worsening.

no.title: Phenoxymethylpenicillin (first line)
formulations: Oral suspension 125 mg/5 mL, 250 mg/5 mL
no.route: Oral on an empty stomach (30 minutes before food or 2 hours after).
plus: Advise swallowing tablets whole with water; avoid double doses if one missed.
Continue analgesia and fluids even when antibiotic supplied.
no.followUp: Return if symptoms fail to improve after completing 5 days or worsen rapidly.

no.title: Shared decision: supportive care
actions: Patient opts for self-care first; provide analgesia plan and reassurance.
Agree review if symptoms remain severe after 3 days; consider delayed prescription if clinically appropriate.
Document discussion using TARGET RTI resources.
no.followUp: Pharmacist reassessment if no improvement within 3–5 days.
